texto_por_actor.Arab Republic of Egypt: Egypt loses Ethiopia's cooperation in future Nile negotiations
texto_por_actor.Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia: Ethiopia experiences reduced bargaining power in future Nile negotiations
texto_por_actor.Republic of Sudan: Sudan loses bargaining power in future Nile negotiations

Arab Republic of Egypt.texto: Egypt demands a legally binding agreement (not voluntary guidelines) that obliges Ethiopia to release guaranteed minimum flows during drought years to prevent irreversible damage. Invokes the international principle of 'no significant harm' and its historical rights based on the 1929 and 1959 treaties. Declares that all options remain open to protect its vital resource.
Egypt escalates diplomatic pressure on Ethiopia through international forums
Egypt potentially alienates Ethiopia from diplomatic cooperation
Egypt loses Ethiopia's cooperation in future Nile negotiations

Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia.texto: Ethiopia invokes the principle of 'Equitable and Reasonable Utilization' recognized in customary international law, rejecting the 1929 and 1959 treaties as valid legal basis. Proposes flexible and revisable operational guidelines that do not restrict its future development rights, arguing that a rigid treaty would perpetuate historical inequities. Maintains that flow regulation will benefit the region by stabilizing discharge and reducing floods.
Ethiopia avoids binding commitments that could limit future Nile development projects
Ethiopia faces increased diplomatic pressure from downstream countries
Ethiopia experiences reduced bargaining power in future Nile negotiations

Republic of Sudan.texto: Sudan conditions its acceptance on the implementation of a robust real-time technical data exchange mechanism (daily/hourly). While acknowledging that the GERD can control seasonal floods affecting Khartoum and reduce sedimentation at Roseires, it considers unacceptable the operational risk of a 74 billion cubic meter dam upstream without binding coordination, fearing the collapse of its own irrigation and electricity generation systems.
Sudan's Roseires Dam operations become dependent on Ethiopian data sharing
Sudan's national sovereignty over water management becomes compromised
Sudan must accept subordinate status in regional water governance
Sudan loses bargaining power in future Nile negotiations

hubs.texto: Egypt loses Ethiopia's cooperation in future Nile negotiations

Ethiopia positions itself as regional stabilizer rather than threat to water security

While acknowledging that the GERD can control seasonal floods affecting Khartoum and reduce sedimentation at Roseires, it considers unacceptable the operational risk of a 74 billion cubic meter dam upstream without binding coordination, fearing the collapse of its own irrigation and electricity generation systems.
Sudan must maintain technical teams for continuous GERD data monitoring
Sudan develops technical expertise in transboundary water management systems
Sudan becomes valuable technical partner for other riparian states
Sudan gains leverage in regional water negotiations
